abstract.p: Gail Parker and Sharon Lieberman letters on Peggy Orenstein's April 1 article on women who are desperate to conceive a baby

block.p: Well, of course, women who eat ice cream at least twice a week have a lower risk of infertility (Peggy Orenstein, April 1). Babies aren't stupid. They need some assurance that they'll be eating well for those nine months in the womb. Because once they're born, it'll be just milk and gruel for months.

Well, of course, women who eat ice cream at least twice a week have a lower risk of infertility (Peggy Orenstein, April 1). Babies aren't stupid. They need some assurance that they'll be eating well for those nine months in the womb. Because once they're born, it'll be just milk and gruel for months.

My own 1970s New York City group of feminist activists (called a ''collective'' back then) was concerned about reproductive rights, which included being pregnant or not being pregnant. I wish Orenstein had cited at least one ''feminist'' source where childlessness by choice is promoted. Our culture does not fetishize motherhood, as Orenstein suggests, but commodifies it. A baby is the new accessory.
